Dear Mr. Porter:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
6/18/18-6/20/18. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following

(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.

records did not have the references dated or they were dated
after employment started.

An institution shall maintain employee records for each

RFCAN Contract Oct 17: 2.10.i. Page 19 Contractor Responsibilities-Services to
be Provided-Family Team Meetings
Upon admission, the Contractor shall coordinate with the MDHHS
caseworker/PAFC provider responsible for placement, the family and the child
to identify members of the child’s team for ongoing participation in the case
planning Family Team Meetings facilitated by MDHHS/PAFC or designee. The
Contractor shall incorporate relevant planning goals/action steps regarding the
child(ren) from previous Family Team Meetings into the Contractor developed
initial case plan due 30 days from admission. The Contractor and child(ren)
shall participate in quarterly Case Planning Family Team Meetings facilitated by
the assigned MDHHS caseworker/PAFC provider/designee, and align
Contractor developed quarterly case plans with Family Team Meeting/Parent
Agency Treatment plans.
For youth who are developmentally appropriate to participate in a Family Team
Meeting, the Contractor shall facilitate a Pre-Meeting Discussion with the child
at least 24 hours prior to the Family Team Meeting. The Contractor shall
participate with the youth in person or via phone conference at all Case
Planning/Case Plan Reassessment Family Team Meeting.
Six opened residential files were reviewed. Three files were under the Abuse/Neglect
contract. A total of five FTM’s were to be conducted within those files. Four out of five
were not completed. REPEAT VIOLATION
RFCAN Contract Oct 17: 2.10.1)d) Page 27 Contractor Responsibilities-Services
to be Provided-Transitional Service Following Discharge-Planned Discharge-
Medication

The contractor shall provide medical information, including a medication
regime, a complete Prescription Information form (DHHS-2840) signed by the
Contractor’s medical staff or clinical supervisor, and at least a 14-day supply of
medication to the responsible party at the time of discharge.
Eight closed residential files were reviewed. Four files were under the Abuse/Neglect
contract. Two out of four files did not have the DHHS-2840 in the file.
RFCAN Contract Oct 17: 2.10.1)e) Page 27 Contractor Responsibilities-Services
to be Provided-Transitional Service Following Discharge-Planned Discharge-
Contact
Assign a social services worker to maintain contact with the child and family
for the first 30 calendar days following discharge, if the child is placed in a
family setting. Contact shall include at least two home visits within the 30
calendar day period and at least one successful phone contact per week to both
the parent and child for 30 calendar days following discharge to assist in re-
establishing family equilibrium.
Four closed files were under the Abuse/neglect contract. Only one was a planned
discharge. One out of one file did not have transitional services provided.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has not
been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
Two employee records showed the employee lived out of state
within the last five years. One employee lived in Illinois in 2017
12

and the other employee lived in Alabama in 2014. The agency
was provided the Adam Walsh State Contacts for Child Abuse
Registry in order to obtain the documents needed for those who
have resided outside the state of Michigan.
R 400.4156 I n s t i t utions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions;
updated treatment plan.
(3) The updated treatment plan shall include all of the
following information:
(b) Progress made toward achieving the goals established
in the previous treatment plan.
All updated treatment plans did provide a generic progress
statement. The treatment plan either stated “progress-no” or
“progress-some”. The intent of this rule is to assure that children
in care are evaluated and receive the appropriate services to
meet their needs, that they are not in care longer than
necessary or the duration of the court order, and that they
achieve timely permanence. A generic statement not outlining
where the resident is in achieving the previous goal does not
allow the reader to determine what services have been provided
to the resident, based on the agency’s program statement, and
how far away or how close they are to achieving those goals. It
was discussed with the agency that the report needs to address
the services the resident has been receiving to accomplish the
goals as well as describe where the resident is at in completing
the action steps, specified by the time frames noted in the
reports.
R 400.4166 Discharge Plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following:
(d)Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge
None of the closed resident files provided a statement
noting whether services would be provided after
discharge or not. The agency does not provide services
after the resident is discharged, unless the resident falls
under the abuse/neglect contract. The agency was
unaware of the services that needed to be provided to the
residents under the abuse/neglect contract. Because of
this, they were not providing any statement in the
discharge plan because they did not believe it applied to
13

them. The agency will need to write a statement in the
discharge plan outlining the services they will provide or a
statement acknowledging that no services will be
provided.
R 400.4144 A d m i s s i o n h e alth screening; physical examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed for each
resident within 24 hours of admission to a facility.
The agency medical policy was reviewed. No information was
documented concerning an initial health screening. There were no
forms in any of the open residential files noting an initial health
assessment was completed. Information could be gathered from
multiple documents in the file that could collectively be an initial
health screen. It was discussed to add Initial health screening in
the policy. A form may need to be created, depending on how the
policy is written.
RFCAN Contract Oct 17: 2.10.d. page 13 Contractor
Responsibilities-Services to be Provided-Staffing: The
Contractor shall designate individual(s) trained in making
decisions using the reasonable and prudent parent standard
and who are authorized to consent to the youth's
participation in activities. A designated individual(s) is to be
onsite to exercise the reasonable and prudent parent
standard. The designated individual shall take reasonable
steps to determine the appropriateness of the activity in
consideration of the child's age, maturity, and developmental
level. The designated individual(a) is to consult with social
work or treatment staff who are most familiar with the child at
the residential program in applying and using the reasonable
and prudent parent standard.
REASONABLE AND PRUDENT PARENT STANDARD: Foster
children have the right to participate in age and
developmentally appropriate activities that are accepted as
suitable for children of the same chronological age or level of
maturity. The Reasonable and Prudent Parent Standard is a
standard of decision making that allows a caregiver to make
routine parenting decisions regarding the participation in
extracurricular, enrichment, cultural, and social activities.
The standard is characterized by careful and sensible
parental decisions that maintain a child's health, safety, and
best interests while encouraging the emotional and
developmental growth of the child. Caregivers may make
certain decisions, similar to daily decisions that a parent is
expected to make, regarding the child's participation in
activities without prior approval of the child’s caseworker, the
licensing or approval agency, or the juvenile court.
14

Employees are not being trained on the above standard. It was
discussed that the supervisors of direct care workers could
complete the training, and this would then be in compliance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR-2017C0325009: The agency did not have policies on the staff members’
roles in the school.
The agency created a policy outlining staff roles in the school.
Interim 2017:
R 400.4152: NO REPEATS
R 400.4155 (3) (4): REPEAT VIOLATIONS
R 400.4156 (2) (3): REPEAT VIOLATIONS
R 400.4166 (1): REPEAT VIOLATIONS
RFCAN 2.10.i.: REPEAT VIOLATIONS
RFCAN 2.10.R: NO REPEATS
Through file review it was determined the agency has organized files, both with
employee records and residential files. The intake process for a resident is done well
and all documentation is completed thoroughly. The agency also completes an
“Admissions Assessment Form” which is detailed and helpful to any reader of the
resident files. Treatment plans had excellent client centered goals and action steps.
Through interviews with residents and staff, it was clear services are being provided. All
residents reported they liked where they were placed and have been receiving help
through the variety of services provided.
In the upcoming year, the agency will need to attend to report writing. Repeat violations
were cited in the initial treatment plans, updated treatment plans and discharge plans.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
